<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
  /* Do not use sysctl() function on GNU/Linux even if
     sysctl() is available */
#ifndef __linux__
#ifdef HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, Darwin (and others?): The number of CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.ncpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME */
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCTL) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_CTL_HW) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_HW_NCPU)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, Darwin (and others?): The number of CPUs */
    int mib[2] = {CTL_HW, HW_NCPU};
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    if ((0 != sysctl (mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTL && HAS_DECL_CTL_HW && HAS_DECL_HW_NCPU */
#endif /* ! __linux__ */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```

explanation: I flagged the two calls to external functions (sysctlbyname and sysctl) because indirect recursion could occur only via calls to other functions that might (directly or indirectly) call back into mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_. All other fragments in the function are simple/local constructs (variable declarations/initializations, comparisons, assignments, preprocessor conditionals, and return statements) that do not invoke other functions or use function pointers/callbacks and therefore cannot introduce direct or indirect self-calls. There are no function-pointer invocations, no calls to macros that expand to function calls, and no other function-call sites in this code to investigate for recursion.
